subtitle: Great Divinity Illuminating Heaven

hoverInfo.quick: Supreme deity of Shinto, divine ancestor of the Imperial line

name: Amaterasu-Omikami

narratives.title: Birth from Izanagi's Purification
narratives.summary: Born from Izanagi's left eye during his misogi (purification) after fleeing Yomi. Assigned to rule the High Plain of Heaven (Takamagahara).
narratives.significance: Establishes her as product of purification - purity central to her nature

narratives.title: The Cave of Heaven (Iwato-gakure)
narratives.summary: Angered by Susanoo's violent outrages, Amaterasu retreated into the Heavenly Rock Cave, plunging the world into darkness. The eight million kami devised a plan: they hung Yata no Kagami and magatama jewels on a sakaki tree, and the goddess Ame-no-Uzume performed an ecstatic dance. When Amaterasu peeked out at the laughter, Ame-no-Tajikarao pulled her forth and light returned to the world.
narratives.significance: Origin of ritual, dance, and mirrors in Shinto worship. Explains solar eclipses.

narratives.title: The Contest with Susanoo (Ukehi)
narratives.summary: When Susanoo came to heaven claiming good intentions, Amaterasu challenged him to prove his sincerity through ukehi (oath-making). She chewed his sword and spat forth three female kami; he chewed her magatama jewels and spat forth five male kami, including Ame-no-Oshihomimi, ancestor of the Imperial line.
narratives.significance: Establishes the divine lineage that leads to the Imperial family

narratives.title: The Descent of Ninigi (Tenson Korin)
narratives.summary: Amaterasu sent her grandson Ninigi to rule the Central Land of Reed Plains (Japan). She bestowed upon him the Three Sacred Treasures: Yata no Kagami (mirror), Yasakani no Magatama (jewel), and Kusanagi no Tsurugi (sword). Ninigi's great-grandson became Emperor Jimmu.
narratives.significance: Divine mandate for imperial rule over Japan

search.searchableText: amaterasu-omikami great divinity illuminating heaven sun goddess shinto imperial ise grand shrine takamagahara

description: Amaterasu-Omikami is the supreme deity of Shinto, the radiant sun goddess who rules over Takamagahara (the High Plain of Heaven) and serves as the divine ancestor of the Japanese Imperial line. Her light sustains all life, her wisdom guides the kami, and her sacred mirror remains the most treasured of Japan's Imperial Regalia.

historicalContext.historicalPeriod: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)

shrineSites.name: Ise Grand Shrine (Ise Jingu)
shrineSites.significance: Holiest site in Shinto, dwelling of Amaterasu. Houses Yata no Kagami sacred mirror.
shrineSites.notes: Ritually rebuilt every 20 years (Shikinen Sengu). Current structures rebuilt in 2013 (62nd rebuilding).

shrineSites.name: Amanoiwato Shrine
shrineSites.significance: Built at the legendary site of the cave where Amaterasu hid

shrineSites.name: Hinomisaki Shrine
shrineSites.significance: Known as the 'Sunset Shrine' complementing Ise's sunrise worship

festivalAssociations.name: Kannamesai
festivalAssociations.significance: Most important festival at Ise, offering first rice harvest to Amaterasu

festivalAssociations.name: Niinamesai
festivalAssociations.significance: The Emperor offers new rice to Amaterasu - one of the most important imperial rites

festivalAssociations.name: Shikinen Sengu
festivalAssociations.significance: 20-year shrine rebuilding ceremony, most recently in 2013

festivalAssociations.name: Shogatsu (New Year)
festivalAssociations.significance: Millions visit shrines to receive Amaterasu's blessing for the year

buddhistEquivalents.connection: Honji suijaku - Amaterasu as manifestation of Cosmic Buddha

imperialConnections.sacredRegalia: Yata no Kagami (Sacred Mirror) - one of Three Imperial Treasures
imperialConnections.legitimacy: Divine right of imperial rule derives from descent from Amaterasu

historicalNotes: Divine ancestor of Japanese Imperial line through grandson Ninigi
Yata no Kagami never publicly displayed - its existence is a matter of faith
Cave myth (Iwato-gakure) explains origin of eclipses and seasonal darkness
First Emperor Jimmu traced lineage to Amaterasu through Ninigi

practices: Temizu (hand washing) purification before approaching shrines
Offerings of rice, sake, salt, and water
Kamidana (home shrines) with sacred mirrors representing Amaterasu's presence
Greeting the sunrise with two claps and a bow
Norito (prayers) thanking her for light, warmth, and life

sacredObjects.name: Yata no Kagami
sacredObjects.description: The sacred eight-span mirror, most important of the Three Imperial Treasures

sacredObjects.name: Sakaki
sacredObjects.description: Sacred evergreen tree (Cleyera japonica) used in purification and offerings

sacredObjects.name: Shimenawa
sacredObjects.description: Sacred rope marking purified spaces, associated with the cave entrance

sacredAnimals: Rooster (Niwatori) - whose crow summoned her from the cave

primary.title: Kojiki
primary.author: O no Yasumaro
primary.description: Record of Ancient Matters - oldest chronicle of Japan

primary.title: Nihon Shoki
primary.author: Prince Toneri et al.
primary.description: Chronicles of Japan - official history with variant accounts

primary.title: Kogo Shui
primary.author: Imbe no Hironari
primary.description: Gleanings from Ancient Stories - additional traditions

primary.title: Engishiki
primary.author: Various
primary.description: Procedures of the Engi Era - detailed ritual instructions

father.name: Izanagi-no-Mikoto
father.relationship: Born from his left eye during purification

siblings.name: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto
siblings.relationship: Moon God, born from right eye

children.name: Five male kami from contest
children.note: Including Ame-no-Oshihomimi, ancestor of Imperial line

grandchildren.name: Ninigi-no-Mikoto
grandchildren.note: Sent to rule Earth, great-grandfather of first Emperor Jimmu

divineRelationships.attendant: Ame-no-Uzume - goddess of dawn who coaxed her from the cave
divineRelationships.rival: Susanoo - her brother whose wild nature stands opposite her ordered brilliance

symbolism.archetype: Sun Deity - supreme celestial power bringing light, life, and cosmic order

historicalEncounter.description: Jesuit missionaries (16th-17th century) and later Protestant missionaries encountered Amaterasu worship as central to Japanese religious identity. The sun goddess's role in imperial ideology complicated Christian mission.
historicalEncounter.significance: The association of Amaterasu with the Japanese imperial line created political dimensions to Christian proclamation of Christ as sole Lord.

typologicalConnections.observation: Amaterasu as sun goddess embodies light and life, paralleling Christ as 'light of the world' (John 8:12).
typologicalConnections.distinction: Amaterasu is the physical sun deified; Christ is Creator of sun and uncreated Light. The sun is created (Genesis 1:16); Christ is eternal.

typologicalConnections.observation: The imperial line's claimed descent from Amaterasu sacralized Japanese political authority.
typologicalConnections.distinction: Christian theology separates divine and human spheres. No human lineage is divine, though rulers receive authority from God (Romans 13:1).

scholarlyEnrichment.methodology: Comparative religion from Christian scholarly perspective, incorporating patristic sources and typological analysis
